content:
Yes, there are many other painters who have contributed significantly to the Prado's collection. Here are a few examples:

1. José de Ribera: This Spanish Baroque painter, also known as "lo Spagnoletto," was known for his dramatic use of chiaroscuro and his depictions of religious and mythological scenes. The Prado has many of his works, including Saint Jerome and The Clubfooted Boy.

2. Raphael: This Italian Renaissance painter was famous for his frescoes and his portraits. The Prado has several of his paintings, including The Holy Family with the Infant Baptist and La Perla.

3. Caravaggio: This Italian Baroque painter was known for his use of dramatic lighting and his realistic depictions of everyday people. The Prado has several of his works, including David with the Head of Goliath and The Crowning with Thorns.

4. Jan van Eyck: This Flemish painter was one of the earliest artists to use oil paints, which allowed him to create highly realistic and detailed portraits. The Prado has several of his works, including The Annunciation and The Crucifixion.

5. Hieronymous Bosch: This Dutch painter was known for his fantastical and often disturbing depictions of hell and sin. The Prado has several of his works, including The Garden of Earthly Delights and The Haywain Triptych.

All of these painters contributed to the Prado's collection by producing high-quality works that are of great historical and cultural significance. Each artist had his own unique style and vision, and together they helped shape the museum's impressive collection.
